title: One of my geth console died while mining
body: All the others are fine, somehow this one keeps dying, see log at: https://gist.github.com/anthony-cros/e79ab51aced97a6d054e
Does this happen consistently over multiple runs? Does it mine for a while and only crash afterwards? Geth version?
Which version of geth?
I an getting the same bug on ubuntu. I am not mining. http://pastebin.com/gcuEbfJR

I also got this

```
I0513 14:06:42.470316    4698 worker.go:226] ðŸ”¨  Mined block #14200
I0513 14:06:42.478105    4698 worker.go:337] commit new work on block 14201 with 0 txs & 0 uncles
panic: runtime error: invalid memory address or nil pointer dereference
[signal 0xb code=0x1 addr=0x0 pc=0x50445a]

goroutine 3564 [running]:
github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/core/types.(*Block).Hash(0x0, 0x0, 0x0, 0x0, 0x0)
    /build/buildd/ethereum-0.9.20+493SNAPSHOT20150512172414trusty/obj-x86_64-linux-gnu/src/github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/core/types/block.go:319 +0xca
github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/core.(*ChainManager).InsertChain(0xc208e5e1e0, 0xc20c47a000, 0x100, 0x400, 0x0, 0x0, 0x0)
    /build/buildd/ethereum-0.9.20+493SNAPSHOT20150512172414trusty/obj-x86_64-linux-gnu/src/github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/core/chain_manager.go:575 +0x130b
github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/eth.(*ProtocolManager).processBlocks(0xc20a8dc900, 0x0, 0x0)
    /build/buildd/ethereum-0.9.20+493SNAPSHOT20150512172414trusty/obj-x86_64-linux-gnu/src/github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/eth/sync.go:64 +0x371
created by github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/eth.(*ProtocolManager).update
    /build/buildd/ethereum-0.9.20+493SNAPSHOT20150512172414trusty/obj-x86_64-linux-gnu/src/github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/eth/sync.go:39 +0x317

goroutine 1 [select]:
gith
```

Full dump at [pastebin](http://pastebin.com/3qUtKNaL)

```
[~]
#geth version

   Welcome to the
      FRONTIER

Geth
Version: 0.9.20
Protocol Version: 60
Network Id: 0
Go Version: go1.4.2
OS: linux
GOPATH=
GOROOT=/usr/lib/go

#uname -a
Linux martin-ThinkPad-T540p 3.13.0-52-generic #86-Ubuntu SMP Mon May 4 04:32:59 UTC 2015 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
```

... And another one. The mining goes fine for a while, then _boom_ 
[Dump at pastebin](http://pastebin.com/iPf8VG43)

Scratch that, it happens even when I'm not mining:

Full dump in [pastebin](http://pastebin.com/cAsQu4s1)

> Does this happen consistently over multiple runs?

Yes it did

> Which version of geth?

I believe this was the very latest release (0.9.20) but I'll have to check (90% sure though)

I tried updating to the latest shiny new in the PPA (`ethereum-0.9.20+495SNAPSHOT20150513110249trusty` instead of `ethereum-0.9.20+493SNAPSHOT20150512172414trusty`). 

Result:

```
> panic: runtime error: invalid memory address or nil pointer dereference
[signal 0xb code=0x1 addr=0x0 pc=0x50455a]
```

Here's the [dump](http://pastebin.com/3g7C6kTt)

@anthony-cros it's displayed in the crash dump (from your dump): 

```
github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/core/types.(*Block).Hash(0x0, 0x0, 0x0, 0x0, 0x0)
/build/buildd/ethereum-0.9.20+19trusty/obj-x86_64-linux-gnu/src/github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/core/types/block.go:319 +0xca
```

You ran version `0.9.20+19`
@holiman cool, thanks!
Did you run the same chain with `0.9.19`?
As for me; I started experimenting with it yesterday, so haven't run any other version than the two variants of `0.9.20` above.
@obscuren it's possible, I don't quite remember... Would they be incompatible?
@anthony-cros there was a problem in pre .20 which could possibly cause this error.

How do I 'reset' my computer; would it be back from 'scratch' if I removed the `.ethereum` and/or `.ethash` directories? Or is there something else I should do to try to get it working again? I have a feeling that something is corrupt, and I'd like to try resetting whatever states/databases I have locally. Oh and I have no local wallets that I care about, so that's not a concern..
If you're on OS X remove `~/Library/Ethereum/blockchain` or on linux `~/.ethereum/blockchain`. Or do a `geth upgradedb`
Another instance of it: https://gist.github.com/anthony-cros/bf6fce90f2f6e5c94f7d, or a different problem (not sure)?

@obscuren thanks, I've upgraded the db, let's see if it happens again. 

On a sidenote, in case it makes any difference to the dumps above: before I ran `geth` normally, I tested with `geth --networkid='-1234'` as specified in the docs to test with my own network. 

Oh, and now it crashed again. Here's the main parts of the dump.. 

```

```
@anthony-cros Your crash was fixed yesterday by https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/pull/954, please update to latest develop.
To be precise, the crash that was fixed was the latest one that @anthony-cros reported, within fetchHashes. The other issue in `Hash()` from `InsertChain` is something else..
Yeah, that's what I've said :D :P

@karalabe thanks, but I can't seem to build (see https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/issues/934) so I have to stick to PPA for now.

The one difference with my latest comment above is that I was able to successfully restart it this time (which wasn't the case with my original post). Note also that geth in that case geth was in "-rpc" mode and ethminer was GPU mining for it. I know ethminer is on the cpp side, but I wouldn't expect it to crash geth. That's what makes me wonder if it could be another issue maybe (note that it doesn't block me since I successfully restarted geth/ethminer)

@anthony-cros yes, your latest issue is another issue altogether, occurring at a different place. Also, it's been fixed. Let's try to keep this issue on the originally reported bug: where stack traces begin like this:

```
github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/core/types.(*Block).Hash(0x0, 0x0, 0x0, 0x0, 0x0)
```
Oh, and I also checked the error message returned from `self.blockDb.Get`; it is `leveldb: not found`
Thanks for all the incredible helpful debugging and output. I'll look in to this immediately!

This is the issue in ASCII (numbers are the TD of the chain). A = the forked chain, B = canonical chain

```
     A  B
        O    10
      / |
12   O  O    13
     |  |
13   O  O    14
     |
14   O
     |
15   O <- attemps to refer to block.N - 1 in the canon chain which doesn't exist
          and throws a nil pointer error
```

Creating fix

I can confirm that it works now. Thanks!

```
I0516 09:44:51.588895    3792 downloader.go:145] Block synchronisation started
I0516 09:46:02.414755    3792 chain_manager.go:670] Fork detected @ dbb21a9c. Reorganising chain from #14233 8433c6f9 to 5eab10c8
I0516 09:46:02.757364    3792 chain_manager.go:627] imported 256 block(s) (0 queued 0 ignored) in 1.923743429s. #14336 [647bba9a / 488d4e0b]
```
